question: Will the USDA-posted recall by Yu Shang Food, Inc. of Ready-To-Eat Meat and Poultry Products issued November 21, 2024 be closed before March 1, 2025?
description: According to the USDA: "Yu Shang Food, Inc., a Spartanburg, SC, establishment, is recalling approximately 72,240 pounds of ready-to-eat (RTE) meat and poultry products within their shelf life that may be adulterated with Listeria monocytogenes, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS). This release is being reissued to expand the scope of the [November 9, 2024](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/yu-shang-food-inc--recalls-ready-eat-meat-and-poultry-products-due-possible-listeria), recall."
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**95 cases of food sales suspension and recall in 2024, with 'other processed foods' being the most common**
According to the Ministry of Food and Drug Safety, there were 95 cases of food sales suspension and recall in 2024, an increase of 1 case from the previous year. The majority of these cases were related to 'other processed foods', which include products such as 'Hwachunhwan' and 'Boswelia-hwan'. These products accounted for 15 cases, a 5-fold increase from the previous year. The increase in cases of other processed foods is attributed to some companies violating food safety laws by selling multiple types of processed foods without proper registration and notification. One such company, Je-hwan-so in Daegu, was found to have sold five types of products that were not registered or notified, and were subsequently suspended and recalled in November 2024. The 'Hwachunhwan' product, in particular, was found to have used an unapproved ingredient, 'Bogolji', which is not suitable for use as a food ingredient. Another product, 'Cheongeumchae-hwan', was found to contain the food poisoning bacteria 'Clostridium perfringens'. Other cases of food sales suspension and recall include a product made from fresh barley, which was found to have violated food safety laws. In contrast, the number of cases related to instant-cooked foods decreased from 18 in 2023 to 5 in 2024. The most common reasons for food sales suspension and recall in 2024 were non-compliance with food standards (67 cases), followed by food safety law violations (15 cases), and food labeling and advertising law violations (13 cases).
Original language: ko
Publish date: January 29, 2025 09:28 PM
Source:[연합뉴스](https://www.yna.co.kr/view/AKR20250124144800017)

**USDA issues health alert for Wegmans chicken nuggets due to bone fragments**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service issued a public health alert for frozen, fully cooked Wegmans breaded chicken breast nuggets due to possible contamination with bone fragments. The affected product, with a 'best if used by' date of August 26, 2025, was produced on August 26, 2024, and distributed to Wegmans locations in several states. Although a recall was not requested since the product is no longer available for purchase, consumers are urged not to consume it and to throw it away or return it to the place of purchase, as stated by the FSIS announcement, 'FSIS is concerned that some product may be in consumers' freezers.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 06:59 PM
Source:[NBC News](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/usda-issues-health-alert-wegmans-chicken-nuggets-due-bone-fragments-rcna189848)

**Wegmans chicken nugget recall: Map shows states impacted**
Wegmans has issued a recall of its frozen chicken nuggets due to reports of bone fragments being found in the product. The recall affects multiple states and has prompted a warning from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS). Consumers are advised not to eat the affected product, which was distributed in Delaware, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. According to the FSIS, the recall was initiated after Wegmans received multiple consumer complaints about finding bone fragments in the nuggets. Wegmans has stated that consumers can return the affected product for a full refund. The FSIS and FDA frequently issue recalls due to contamination concerns, mislabeling, or the presence of foreign materials in food products.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 05:39 PM
Source:[Newsweek](https://www.newsweek.com/wegmans-chicken-nugget-recall-map-shows-states-impacted-2022972)

**USDA issues health alert for Wegmans frozen chicken nuggets that may contain bone fragments**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) has issued a public health alert for some Wegmans frozen chicken nuggets due to the potential presence of bone fragments. The affected products, produced on August 26, 2024, were sold in 46-ounce packages with a 'best if used by' date of August 26, 2025. Consumers are advised not to consume the product and to throw it away or return it to the place of purchase. According to FSIS, there have been no confirmed reports of injury due to consumption of these products. Consumers can contact Wegmans at (855) 934-3663 or the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline at 888-674-6854 for more information.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 04:25 PM
Source:[ABC News](https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Food/usda-issues-health-alert-wegmans-frozen-chicken-nuggets/story?id=118213188)

**US: Why Wegmans is recalling chicken nuggets**
Wegmans is recalling its frozen, fully cooked breaded chicken breast nuggets after bone fragments were discovered in some of the meat. The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service issued a public health alert on January 29, 2025, following multiple consumer complaints. The recall affects 46-oz. plastic packages of 'Wegmans Family Pack Fully Cooked Breaded Chicken Breast with Rib Meat' with a best-used-by date of July 26, 2025. The affected product was sold in eight states and Washington, D.C. The USDA advises consumers to immediately dispose of the product or return it to Wegmans for a refund, as no injuries have been reported.

Publish date: January 29, 2025 04:20 PM
Source:[tribuneonlineng.com](https://tribuneonlineng.com/us-why-wegmans-is-recalling-chicken-nuggets/)

**Wegmans recalls chicken nuggets after bone fragments found in meat: See states impacted**
Wegmans is recalling its frozen, fully cooked breaded chicken breast nuggets after bone fragments were found in some of the meat. The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service issued a public health alert on Monday, and Wegmans issued a voluntary recall on January 24. The product was distributed to retail locations in eight states, and although it has not been in stores for months, some customers may have frozen the product for later consumption. According to the USDA, there have been no reports of injury from the product, and customers who purchased the chicken nuggets should immediately throw them away or return it to Wegmans for a refund. As stated by the USDA, 'Customers who have purchased these products are urged not to consume them.'

**Bone fragments reported in frozen chicken nuggets: USDA**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) issued a public health alert for Wegmans Frozen Fully Cooked Chicken Nuggets due to the potential presence of bone fragments. The affected product, packaged in 46-ounce plastic packages with a 'best if used by' date of August 26, 2025, was distributed exclusively to Wegmans Food Markets in several states. Consumers are advised not to consume this product, and a recall is unnecessary since it is no longer available for purchase. For further inquiries, consumers can contact the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline at 888-674-6854.

**FSAI: 2 food recalls issued for breaded chicken and ready meals**
The Food Safety Authority of Ireland (FSAI) has issued two separate food recall notices for breaded chicken products and ready meals. The first recall is for specific batches of Marks and Spencer breaded chicken products due to the possible presence of salmonella, with 'use by' dates of January 26, January 30, January 31, and February 1, 2025. The second recall is for all batches and 'use by' dates of Gleesons Butchers ready meals, which were produced in an unapproved establishment. Consumers are advised not to eat the implicated batches, and retailers are requested to remove the products from sale and display recall notices at point-of-sale. According to the FSAI, people infected with salmonella typically develop symptoms between 12 and 36 hours after infection, which can include diarrhoea, fever, headache, and abdominal cramps.

Publish date: January 28, 2025 02:40 PM
Source:[agriland.ie](https://www.agriland.ie/farming-news/fsai-2-food-recalls-issued-for-breaded-chicken-and-ready-meals/)

**Rospotrebnadzor HMAO Removes Over Four Tons of Substandard Products**
The Rospotrebnadzor of the Khanty-Mansiysk Autonomous Okrug (HMAO) has removed over four tons of substandard products from circulation in 2024. The majority of the hazardous goods were milk products, sweets, and meat, according to the agency. 'In 2024, more than 22,000 samples of food products were tested, of which 3.1% did not meet the established requirements. The largest violations were found in milk and dairy products (8.2%), confectionery (7.5%), and meat products (4.4%),' the Rospotrebnadzor report for 2024 states. Violations were also found in poultry and eggs, culinary products, alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages, vegetable oils, juices and nectars, baked goods, fish and vegetable products. Some products had false information on the packaging (40.8%), products were sold without documents confirming safety (4.8%). A counterfeit product (2.6%) was also found. As a result, 66 cases were opened and over 50 fines were issued totaling almost two million rubles. In total, Rospotrebnadzor specialists conducted 354 on-site inspections and 752 preventive visits to enterprises engaged in the production and circulation of food products.

**Frozen Chicken Nuggets Recall Hits New York State**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) has issued a public health alert for frozen, fully cooked Wegmans breaded chicken breast nuggets that may be contaminated with bone fragments. The product, produced on August 26, 2024, is no longer available for purchase, but FSIS is urging consumers to throw it away or return it to the place of purchase. The affected product is 46-oz. plastic packages with a 'best if used by' date of 08 26 25, and bears the establishment number 'P-33944' inside the USDA mark of inspection. Consumers who have purchased this product are advised not to consume it, and anyone concerned about an injury should contact a healthcare provider.

**A Second Infant Dies of Listeria from RTE Chinese Products**
A second infant has died due to listeria contamination in ready-to-eat Chinese-style meat and poultry products. The Centers for Disease Control reported 19 cases, with 17 hospitalizations, across eight states. The USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service announced steps to strengthen oversight of food processing facilities, particularly for listeria monocytogenes and ready-to-eat products. According to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, only one of the babies and the mother in a California case were confirmed to have listeria, while the other twin baby's cause of death is still unknown. 'At least seven of the cases were related to pregnancy,' said the CDC. The recall of nearly 77,000 lbs. of affected products was initiated by Yu Shang Food Inc. in November.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 27, 2024 12:00 AM
Source:[foodprocessing.com](https://www.foodprocessing.com/food-safety/news/55252100/a-second-infant-dies-of-listeria-from-rte-chinese-products)

**CDPH issues warning**
The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has issued a warning about Yu Shang Food's ready-to-eat meat and poultry products, which have been linked to a multi-state outbreak of Listeria monocytogenes. The outbreak has resulted in severe illness, hospitalization, and the tragic deaths of two newborns. The CDPH advises consumers and retailers to dispose of or return any products made before October 28, 2024, and to sanitize surfaces that may have come into contact with these products. Dr. Tomás J. Aragón, CDPH Director, stated, 'Our hearts go out to the families affected by this outbreak. We are working tirelessly to ensure public safety and prevent further harm.' The high-risk groups include pregnant individuals, newborns, adults aged 65+, and immunocompromised individuals.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 21, 2024 12:00 AM
Source:[wattagnet.com](https://www.wattagnet.com/latest-news/press-release/15710945/cdph-issues-warning)

**More Calif. hospitalizations in listeria case that killed infant**
A listeria outbreak linked to Yu Shang Food Inc.'s ready-to-eat meat and poultry items has infected 19 individuals across eight states, with 17 hospitalizations reported. The outbreak, which started in October 2021, has claimed the lives of three U.S. infants, including two in California. According to the CDC, a mother and her twin infants became ill, and both infants died. The California Department of Public Health has urged people to avoid consuming the recalled meat products. 'The outbreak highlights the importance of proper food handling and storage to prevent listeria contamination,' said the CDC. California has reported 10 illnesses to date.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 14, 2024 06:15 PM
Source:[knowledia.com](https://news.knowledia.com/US/en/articles/more-calif-hospitalizations-in-listeria-case-that-killed-infant-508d307e9d899aa350224e62a6bf33508b09f106)

**Consumers warned to avoid meat products linked to deadly listeria outbreak as cases rise**
The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has warned consumers to avoid ready-to-eat meat and poultry products made by Yu Shang Food Inc. due to a multistate listeria outbreak that has killed two infants and infected 19 people across eight states. The outbreak is linked to over 72,000 pounds of recalled products, which were mainly sold in Asian grocery stores and online. CDPH Director Tomás Aragón said, 'The consumption of these food products can result in devastating consequences, and our hearts go out to the family and loved ones of the infants who passed away.' The agency advises Californians to not eat, serve or sell the recalled products, and to sanitize any surfaces that may have touched the products. People in higher-risk groups who experience flu-like symptoms after eating possibly contaminated food should seek medical attention immediately.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 12, 2024 01:05 AM
Source:[sfchronicle.com](https://www.sfchronicle.com/health/article/consumers-warned-avoid-meat-linked-deadly-19974488.php)

**California health officials report Listeria outbreak after 2 infants die**
The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has issued a warning about Yu Shang Food ready-to-eat meat and poultry products, which are suspected to be the cause of a multi-state Listeria outbreak. According to the CDPH, 19 Asian people, including 10 from California, have fallen ill, and two newborn infants have died. Dr. Tomas Aragon, CDPH Director and State Public Health Officer, said, 'The consumption of these food products can result in devastating consequences, and our hearts go out to the family and loved ones of the infants who passed away.' All Yu Shang Food brand products made before October 28, 2024 have been recalled. The CDPH advises Californians not to eat, serve, or sell the recalled products, and to sanitize any surfaces that may have touched them. Symptoms of Listeria infection include fever, headache, and neck stiffness.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 12, 2024 12:41 AM
Source:[kron4.com](https://www.kron4.com/news/bay-area/california-health-officials-report-listeria-outbreak-after-2-infants-die/)

**Listeria Outbreak Linked to Chinese-American Company Yu Shang Food, Inc. Claims Another Infant Life**
A new case of infant death has been reported due to a Listeria outbreak linked to Yu Shang Food, Inc., a Chinese-American company. According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there are now 19 confirmed cases, with 17 people hospitalized. The cases are from eight states, including California, Georgia, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, and Tennessee. CDC stated that seven of the cases are related to pregnancy. In Tennessee, a mother and her infant both contracted Listeria, resulting in the infant's death. In California, a mother and her twin infants were infected, with both infants dying. However, since Listeria was only found in the mother and one infant's samples, only the mother and one infant are included in the current outbreak's confirmed cases. The outbreak is linked to Yu Shang Food, Inc.'s ready-to-eat products, including poultry, pork, and beef items, which are sold nationwide and available online. The CDC noted, 'The true number of people infected may be higher than the reported number, and the outbreak may not be limited to the states where cases have been reported.' The US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) initially announced a recall of Yu Shang Food, Inc.'s products on November 9, 2024, and updated the notice on November 25, 2024, to include all ready-to-eat products produced by the company before October 28, 2024. Listeria infection can cause symptoms such as fever, muscle pain, headache, neck stiffness, confusion, loss of balance, and seizures, and may also lead to diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. Invasive infections can spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. Pregnant women who contract Listeria may experience miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, or newborn infection, which can be life-threatening. Additionally, older adults and people with weakened immune systems are more susceptible to severe and potentially life-threatening infections.
Original language: zh
Publish date: December 11, 2024 11:39 PM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/24/12/11/n14389321.htm)

**CDPH Urges Consumers Not to Eat Yu Shang Food, Inc. Meat, Poultry Products**
The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) is warning consumers not to eat, serve or sell Yu Shang Food, Inc. ready-to-eat meat and poultry products due to a multi-state outbreak of Listeria monocytogenes infections. The products, made before October 28, 2024, have been recalled and are suspected to be the cause of 19 cases of Listeria infections in 8 states, including 10 cases in California, resulting in the deaths of 2 newborn infants. Dr. Tomás J. Aragón, CDPH Director and State Public Health Officer, said, 'The consumption of these food products can result in devastating consequences, and our hearts go out to the family and loved ones of the infants who passed away.' Consumers are advised to check their refrigerators and freezers for the recalled products, which have a long shelf life, and to throw them away or return them to the place of purchase. Listeria can survive in the refrigerator and freezer and can easily spread to other foods and surfaces. Symptoms of Listeria infection may include fever, headache, and neck stiffness, and adults over age 65, pregnant persons and their newborns, and those who are immunocompromised are at the highest risk for severe infections and complications.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 11, 2024 11:34 PM
Source:[scvnews.com](https://scvnews.com/cdph-urges-consumers-not-to-eat-yu-shang-food-inc-ready-to-eat-meat-and-poultry-products/)

**Second baby dies in listeria outbreak linked to recalled meat**
A second baby has died in a listeria outbreak linked to recalled meat and poultry products, including Yu Shang Food ready-to-eat meals. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a total of 19 cases have been reported across eight states, with 17 hospitalizations. At least seven of the cases were related to pregnancy. The earliest case occurred in October 2021, but the bulk of the cases were reported between December 2023 and October 2024. The CDC notes that the number of cases may be higher since some people may have gotten sick and not been tested for listeria. Yu Shang Food issued a recall for nearly 77,000 pounds of the affected products in November. 'The number of cases may be higher since some people may have gotten sick and not been tested for listeria,' the CDC said. 'We urge everyone to check their freezers and pantries for recalled products and to discard them immediately.'
Original language: en
Publish date: December 10, 2024 09:52 PM
Source:[sg.news.yahoo.com](https://sg.news.yahoo.com/second-baby-dies-listeria-outbreak-215200588.html)

**More Listeria cases, 1 more death tied to Yu Shang Food**
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has announced 8 new cases (19 total), 8 new hospitalizations (17 total), and 1 more death (2 total) in a Listeria outbreak tied to Yu Shang Food ready-to-eat meat and poultry products. All products produced prior to October 28, 2024, have been recalled by Yu Shang Food, Inc. The outbreak has affected 19 patients, with 17 (89%) hospitalized, and all are Asian, with 68% female. Seven cases have been related to pregnancy, with one woman and her twins in California, and a mother and her infant in Tennessee, both experiencing fatal outcomes. The CDC warns that the true number of sick people in this outbreak is likely higher than reported, and the outbreak may not be limited to the states with known illnesses. 'The true number of sick people in this outbreak is likely higher than the number reported, and the outbreak may not be limited to the states with known illnesses,' the CDC said.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 10, 2024 08:47 PM
Source:[CIDRAP](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/listeria/more-listeria-cases-1-more-death-tied-yu-shang-food)

**Another infant dies in outbreak tied to ready-to-eat meat products**
A second infant has died in an 8-state listeria outbreak related to recalled Yu Shang Food ready-to-eat meat and poultry products, according to federal health officials. Nineteen cases are confirmed, with 17 hospitalized, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. The products were sold online and at retail locations nationwide, and people who have gotten sick may not have gotten tested for listeria, which could make the outbreak higher than reported. Those with recalled products should throw them out or return them, officials urged. The recalled products involve those with 'Yu Shang' or 'Yushang' on the label, produced before Oct. 28, 2024.

**Another infant dies in listeria outbreak linked to ready-to-eat meat and poultry products**
A second infant has died in an 8-state listeria outbreak linked to recalled Yu Shang Food ready-to-eat meat and poultry products. Nineteen cases are confirmed, with 17 hospitalized, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The outbreak may be higher than reported, as people who have gotten sick may not have gotten tested for listeria. Listeria can be especially harmful to pregnant people, people age 65 or older, and those with weakened immune systems. Officials urge those with recalled products to throw them out or return them. **USDA Recalls 72,000 Pounds of Ready-to-Eat Chicken, Beef + Pork**
The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has initiated a recall of over 72,000 pounds of ready-to-eat chicken, beef, and pork due to listeria concerns. The recall was expanded on November 25 to include additional products, including any package of ready-to-eat food from Yu Shang Food produced before October 28, 2024. According to the USDA, nearly 30 products have been impacted, and there have been 59 cases and 10 deaths associated with this outbreak. Consumers are urged to check their freezers for affected products and either return them to the place of purchase for a refund or discard them.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 02, 2024 12:00 AM
Source:[kkyr.com](https://kkyr.com/ixp/204/p/usda-meat-recall-2024/)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, most USDA FSIS recalls are closed within a few months after being issued, as the companies involved typically act quickly to resolve the issues outlined in the recall. Recalls vary by complexity, but given the average timeframes, a recall issued on November 21, 2024, would likely close within 3-4 months, putting closure before March 1, 2025. Based on this general observation, initial probabilities can be estimated around 70% for closure within this timeframe.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Company Compliance History
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Yu Shang Food, Inc. has a history of complying promptly with FSIS guidance and recalls, the probability of a quick resolution is higher. Compliance history can streamline resolution processes and interactions with the FSIS, helping to quickly address the recall's underlying issues.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Geographic Distribution
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The broader the geographic distribution of the products, the more complex and lengthy the recall process may become. More markets and locations increase logistical challenges and consumer outreach efforts.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Product Type
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Some products, due to their nature or handling requirements (e.g., RTE or refrigerated items versus frozen), might pose differing levels of difficulty in a recall. If the products involved are straightforward RTE items with limited complexities, this could speed processing.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Severity of Contamination
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If the level of contamination, such as potential pathogens, is high, this may necessitate extended measures to ensure public safety, potentially complicating a swift resolution.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles provide information that a significant amount of Yu Shang Food products, including meat and poultry in question, have been recalled due to listeria concerns. The articles indicate proactive and thorough measures taken by USDA, FSIS, and health departments, which aligns with the typical process of resolving such food safety issues swiftly. Moreover, similar recalls such as those involving Wegmans products show capable and timely handling of recall processes.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: However, the severity of the listeria outbreak linked to Yu Shang Food, resulting in infant deaths and numerous infections, introduces potential complexities and higher scrutiny that could delay the closure of the recall. This suggests potential extended investigations and monitoring by health agencies which may prolong the process.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, food recalls, once announced, often take several months to resolve depending on the severity, scope, and company cooperation. Historically, a review of USDA recalls shows that the majority of recall issues are resolved within a 3 to 6-month time frame. The starting probability that this recall will be closed within approximately 3-4 months from the announcement date (November 21, 2024, to March 1, 2025) is typically around 50%, considering average processing times.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Effectiveness of Recall Management
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: In my field, recall effectiveness checks are crucial. They ensure that the recalled products are effectively removed from the supply chain. Yu Shang Food, Inc.’s past effectiveness in managing recalls can influence resolution time. If the company has historically handled recalls efficiently and complied fully, this makes the closure of the recall before the deadline more likely.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Severity of the Recall
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If the recall's severity is significant, involving potential health risks, this might lead to extended investigations and additional measures by the USDA, possibly delaying the closure. Without specific details of any extreme severity or complications, we assume a moderate impact.

perspective_derived_factors.name: USDA Resources and Prioritization
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The availability of USDA resources and prioritization of recall closure can also affect timelines. If the USDA is experiencing high demand for its resources, it may impact their ability to close recalls quickly. Given no signs of unusual strain or changes in USDA's operational capacity as of the latest update, no adjustment is applied.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles highlight an increase in recalls for various food products due to non-compliance, safety violations, and health issues like presence of Listeria. This indicates active enforcement and monitoring by health authorities, which suggests that recalls are being actively managed, possibly leading to faster closure once a recall is issued.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The Listeria outbreak related to Yu Shang Food, with reports of serious cases and deaths, highlights a severe nature of the recall. This could require extensive investigation and monitoring by authorities, likely leading to delays in closing the recall. Additionally, the recall of nearly 77,000 pounds of products and the ongoing health impacts suggest a complex situation that might extend beyond typical recall resolution timelines.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, USDA recalls for ready-to-eat meat and poultry products typically take varying amounts of time to resolve, depending on the nature of the contamination, distribution scope, and recall classification. In a typical scenario, most recalls are resolved within 3 to 6 months from the date they are issued. Given that the recall in question was issued on November 21, 2024, the time frame until March 1, 2025, represents just over 3 months. Thus, considering historical data, there is a reasonable probability that a recall could be closed within this period, especially if it falls into a less severe classification and involves efficient response mechanisms.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Severity of Contamination
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If the contamination level is considered low-risk or non-pathogenic, the recall process might conclude faster due to less extensive investigation and response being needed.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recall Classification
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If this recall is classified as a Class I, which involves a high health risk, it might take longer to resolve due to the need for thorough inspections and follow-ups, thereby reducing the probability of a quick closure.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Company Compliance and Cooperation
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Yu Shang Food, Inc. is compliant and cooperative with USDA guidelines, the recall process could be expedited, increasing the likelihood of closure.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recall Scope and Distribution
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: A limited distribution scope and fewer affected batches would expedite traceability and corrective actions, potentially reducing the closure time.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Yu Shang Food was initially estimated to have a high likelihood of closing the recall promptly due to potential efficient handling and compliance mechanisms. The recall included substantial efforts to pull products from sale and bolster consumer warnings. The seriousness of the listeria outbreak may prompt accelerated actions to mitigate public health risks, thereby reinforcing an advancement towards closure.
